body:
Shares of Oracle Corporation (ORCL) will begin trading ex-dividend on Tuesday, Jan. 3. To qualify for a dividend check, investors must have owned Oracle shares prior to Tuesday, which is the day the company's management will finalize its roster of shareholders to whom it will mail payments.

Oracle stock closed Friday at $38.45, down 0.62%. The shares ended 2016 with gains of 5.26%, including 2.11% declines in the past three months. This compares with a 9.5% increase in the S&P 500 (SPX) index for 2016. Oracle stock has risen 4.11% over the past 12 months, while the S&P 500 has risen almost 10%. (See also: Oracle Co-CEO to Meet With Donald Trump.)

In its fiscal second quarter earnings results, reported last month, the Redwood City, Calif.-based company beat Wall Street estimates on earnings per share but missed on revenue. The company reported adjusted earnings of 61 cents per share, which beat analysts' projections by 1 cent, while revenue of $9.07 billion grew 0.83% year over year, missing Wall Street estimates by about $50 million. (See also: Oracle Expands Cloud Solutions With Acquisition.)

For the quarter ending February, Oracle is expected to deliver earnings of 56 cents per share, down from 64 cents per share a year ago, while revenue of $9.25 billion would rise 3% year over year. For the full year, ending May, earnings are projected decline about 2% year over year to $2.56 per share, while revenue of $37.53 billion would mark a 1.7% rise year over year. (See also: 3 Things to Consider Ahead of Oracle Earnings.)

Based on Friday's closing price of $38.45, Oracle's 15-cent per share quarterly dividend yields 1.56% annually, or about 44 basis points below the 2.00% average yield of the S&P 500 index. Oracle will send its dividend payment on Jan. 26 to shareholders of record as of Jan. 5. The stock has a consensus Buy rating and an average analyst 12-month price target of $44, implying a rise of 14% from current levels.
title: Oracle Stock Trades Ex-Dividend Tuesday
